DOCNAME: CASE OF WHITFIELD AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1 in respect of three applicants;Violation of Art. 6-3-c in respect of all applicants;Not necessary to examine Art. 6-3-b;No violation of Art. 5 alone or in conjunction with Art. 13;Non-pecuniary damage - findings of violations sufficient (with regard to three applicants);Non-pecuniary damage - financial award (with regard to one applicant);Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings

CARDINAL . The ORG refers to the law and practice outlined in the case of Ezeh and PERSON v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , ORG . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , § § DATE , ORG CARDINALX ) .

CARDINAL . A charge was , in general , drawn up by a prison officer against whom the alleged offence was committed or who witnessed or dealt with the incident during which the alleged offence took place . Such reporting officers could consult a more senior officer on what charges were to be laid against the prisoner . A charge was formally laid when form a Notice of Report was handed to the accused . A charge had to be laid as soon as possible and , save in exceptional circumstances , within TIME of the alleged offence being discovered .

Every charge laid against a prisoner had to be inquired into by the prison governor . The governor also determined the charge against the accused during the adjudication hearing and imposed punishments from those available to him under the prison rules .

Since DATE the management of certain prisons has been contracted out to private security companies . All such “ contracted out ” prisons have a “ Controller ” ( a ORG employee ) linking them to ORG and the governors are called “ Directors ” . ORG hearings are conducted by the ORG rather than by the Director .
